work.p: The first of these two lines bears some resemblance to a line in the poem eventually titled "Song of Myself," beginning with "These are the thoughts of all men in all ages and lands" (1855, p. 24).

titleStmt.title: I am not content now
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript was probably written in the early 1850s, as Whitman was composing the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. The ideas and phrasing of the manuscript are similar to those used in the first poem of that edition, eventually titled "Song of Myself." The manuscript has been mounted and framed with a portrait, so an image of the back of the leaf is not currently available.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: "I am not content now with a mere majority. ... I must have the love of all men and all women"
bibl.orgName: Trent Collection of Whitmaniana, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

lg.l:
I am not content now with a mere
majority . . . . I must have the
love of all men and all women,

If there be one left in any country who has
no faith in me, I will travel
to that country, and go to that
one, and stand upright before
him,â€”
